poem:
Title: "The Echo of Invisible Coins"

Miombo woodlands whisper silent secrets,
Housing hallowed breaths of carbon cowboys.
Money rains, captures the sun,
Yet not a glimmer alights on the farmers' furrowed earth.
Potholes punctuate rhythm on gravel roads,
Cars scarce as medical solace.
In this sprawling pasture of plenty,
The poorest perceive not the phantom abundance,
Merely a ripple on Lake Kariba's cheek.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘We don’t know where the money is going’: the ‘carbon cowboys’ making millions from credit schemes In the districts surrounding Lake Kariba in Zimbabwe, most people have little idea their villages were at the centre of a multimillion-dollar carbon boom. Punctuated by straw-thatched mud houses, the Miombo woodlands on the edge of the enormous artificial lake are mostly home to smallholder farmers. The gravel roads are full of potholes; cars are infrequent, as are medical". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
